title: Child Care Data, Reports & Plans - Texas Workforce Commission
text: Child Care Resources View and download Child Care & Early Learning plans, reports, and data. Child Care by the Numbers provides information for the most recent 15 months. TWC updates this information quarterly. CCBN also has historical information (back to 2015). The data include: Participation in Texas Rising Star Number of children served Type of providers that serve children The program’s overall footprint in the state The CCDF State Plan describes how Texas implements the Child Care Development Block Grant and the Child Care Development Fund. TWC submits the plan to the Administration for Children and Families every three years. TWC amends the plan as necessary to reflect new policy or activities during the plan period. The CCDF State Plan describes the following topics related to child care and quality improvement: CCDF Leadership and Coordination with Relevant Systems Promoting Family Engagement through Outreach and Consumer Education Providing Stable Child Care Financial Assistance to Families Ensuring Equal Access to High-Quality Child Care for Low-Income Children Establishing Standards and Monitoring Processes to Ensure the Health and Safety of Child Care Settings Recruiting and Retaining a Qualified and Effective Child Care Workforce Supporting Continuous Quality Improvement Ensuring Grantee Accountability Child Care and Development Fund 2025-2027 State Plan Child Care and Development Fund 2025-2027 State Plan Appendix 1 In 2021, Texas’ 87th Legislature passed House Bill 619 requiring TWC to prepare a strategic plan for improving the quality of the child care workforce. State law requires TWC to update the plan every three years. On January 6, 2023, the Commission approved the Child Care Workforce Strategic Plan 2023-2025 . As required by the Labor Code, the Child Care Workforce Strategic Plan considered input from a workgroup that consisted of: Child care providers Community stakeholders Child care workers For more information, see The Workgroup Recommendations to Inform the 2022 Texas Child Care Workforce Strategic Plan . Texas Labor Code §302.0043 requires TWC to prepare an Evaluation of Effectiveness of Subsidized Child Care Program. The goal is to analyze the effectiveness of the subsidized child care program in assisting parents to maintain employment. The Labor Code requires TWC to report the results of the evaluation to the legislature no later than January 15 of each odd-numbered year. Report to the 89th Texas Legislature (2025) Report to the 88th Texas Legislature (2023) Report to the 87th Texas Legislature (2021) Report to the 86th Texas Legislature (2019) Report to the 85th Texas Legislature (2017) Report to the 84th Texas Legislature (2015) Board Contract Year 2026 Maximum Provider Payment Rates Effective October 1, 2025 - September 30, 2026 Board Contract Year 2025 Maximum Provider Payment Rates Effective October 1, 2024 - January 12, 2025 - Four Age Groups Maximum Provider Payment Rates Effective January 13, 2025 - September 30, 2025 - Eight Age Groups Board Contract Year 2024 Maximum Provider Payment Rates Effective October 1, 2023 - September 30, 2024 Income Limits for CCS Eligibility BCY26 Income Limits for CCS Eligibility - Board Contract Year 2026 (effective October 1, 2025 through September 30, 2026) BCY25 Income Limits for CCS Eligibility - Board Contract Year 2025 (effective October 1, 2024 through September 30, 2025) Parent Share of Cost BCY26 Parent Share of Cost Chart (effective October 1, 2025 through September 30, 2026) BCY26 Parent Share of Cost Calculator (effective October 1, 2025 through September 30, 2026) BCY25 Parent Share of Cost Chart (effective January 13, 2025 through September 30, 2025) BCY25 Board Parent Share of Cost Calculator (effective January 13, 2025 through September 30, 2025) The following reports support TWC’s annual process to evaluate and set Child Care Services reimbursement rates: Visit the Texas Institute for Child & Family Wellbeing to see Cost of Quality Reports from 2021 to the present. Child Care Provider Cost of Quality Calculator The Texas Child Care Market Rate Survey reports on child care rates charged to the general public (or the "market rate") in each of the 28 local workforce development areas. Visit the Texas Institute for Child & Family Wellbeing to see Market Rate Surveys from 2012 to the present. Texas Child Care Market Rate Survey Study Methodology A child care desert as an area where the number of children younger than six with working parents is at least three times greater than the capacity of licensed child care providers in the area. Texas Child Care Deserts State law requires Boards to dedicate at least 2 percent of a Board’s annual CCDF allocation to activities that support quality improvement. TWC increased this set aside to 6 percent of each Board’s annual allocation. TWC requires Boards to submit an annual plan and quarterly expenditure reports for these funds. FY25 Board Annual CCQ Expenditure Plans revised on September 24, 2025. FY25 CCQ Quarterly Report revised on September 24, 2025 FY24 Board Annual CCQ Expenditure Plans revised on December 31, 2024. FY24 CCQ Quarterly Reports revised on January 31, 2024. FY23 Board Annual Expenditure Plans Online FY23 CCQ Quarterly Online Report The purpose of the annual Quality Progress Report (QPR) is to capture information on how the state uses CCDF quality funds. The QPR also evaluates progress in improving the quality of child care programs and services for children from birth to age 13. Texas FFY 2021 Child Care Quality Progress Report Texas FFY 2022 Child Care Quality Progress Report Texas FFY 2023 Child Care Quality Progress Report Texas FFY 2024 Child Care Quality Progress Report The Administration for Children and Families (ACF) collects data on children and families served through CCDF. ACF requires all CCDF lead agencies to report this data through the ACF-801 case-level data submission.  The reports include the following: Children Served by County / ZIP Code Families Served by County / ZIP Code Child Care Facilities Providing Services The reports are available at the Texas Open Data Portal . The ACF-800 is TWC's annual aggregate data report on children and families served through CCDF. ACF-800 2023 ACF-800 2022 ACF-800 2021 The ACF-696 is TWC's quarterly financial report submitted to the Administration for Children and Families. ACF-696 Grant Years 2021-2024 Q4 Reports ACF-696 Grant Year 2023 Q2 Report ACF-696 Grant Year 2023Q4 Narrative Response – CRRSA & ARPA Activities ACF-696 Grant Year 2022 Quarterly Reports On June 29, 2021, the Commission approved $30 million of the CCDBG COVID-19 Federal Funding for Texas Rising Star Program Supports Activities.  The funding was issued to Boards in FY22 and had to be expended by March 31, 2023.  Each Board’s plan and the final expenditure and performance summaries were submitted on April 30, 2023. Texas Rising Star Supports Activities Report The Child Care and Development Block Grant (CCDBG) Act of 2014 requires states to have a statewide plan to address child care emergency preparedness, response, and recovery efforts. The plan addresses: Coordinating and collaborating with key partners Guidelines for continuation of child care subsidies and services Coordination of post-disaster recovery of child care services Requirements for CCDF providers and other child care providers Statewide Child Care Emergency Preparedness and Disaster Response Plan
